head.title: Seed Layer Formation on Carbon Electrodes to Control Li2O2 Discharge Products for Practical Li–O2 Batteries with High Energy Density and Reversibility | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Seed Layer Formation on Carbon Electrodes to Control Li2O2 Discharge Products for Practical Li–O2 Batteries with High Energy Density and Reversibility

The high theoretical energy densities of lithium-air batteries (LAB) make this technology an attractive energy storage system for future mobility applications. Li2O2 growth process on the cathode relies on the surrounding chemical environment of electrolytes. Low conductivity and strong reactivity of Li2O2 discharge products can cause overpotential and induce side reactions in LABs, respectively, eventually leading to poor cyclability. The capacity and reversibility of LABs are highly susceptible to the morphology of the Li2O2 discharge products. Here, we identify for the first time that a seed layer formed by the combination of a cathode and an electrolyte determines the morphology of Li2O2 discharge products. This seed layer led to its high reversibility with a large areal capacity (up to 10 mAh/cm2). Excellent OER (oxygen evolution reaction) was achieved by the formation of a favorable interface between the carbon electrode and electrolyte, minimizing the decomposition of the electrolyte. These remarkable improvements in LAB performance demonstrate critical progress toward advancing LAB into practical uses, which would exploit good reversibility of LABs in pouch-type cell arrangements with 1.34 Ah.

div.p:
The high theoretical energy densities of lithium-air batteries (LAB) make this technology an attractive energy storage system for future mobility applications. Li
2
O
2
growth process on the cathode relies on the surrounding chemical environment of electrolytes. Low conductivity and strong reactivity of Li
2
O
2
discharge products can cause overpotential and induce side reactions in LABs, respectively, eventually leading to poor cyclability. The capacity and reversibility of LABs are highly susceptible to the morphology of the Li
2
O
2
discharge products. Here, we identify for the first time that a seed layer formed by the combination of a cathode and an electrolyte determines the morphology of Li
2
O
2
discharge products. This seed layer led to its high reversibility with a large areal capacity (up to 10 mAh/cm
2
). Excellent OER (oxygen evolution reaction) was achieved by the formation of a favorable interface between the carbon electrode and electrolyte, minimizing the decomposition of the electrolyte. These remarkable improvements in LAB performance demonstrate critical progress toward advancing LAB into practical uses, which would exploit good reversibility of LABs in pouch-type cell arrangements with 1.34 Ah.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Lithium air batteries (LAB) are currently considered as one of the most advanced lithium battery systems that offer high intrinsic energy densities (∼3500 Wh/kg). Yet, LAB technology must overcome several challenges for widespread adoption. A critical challenge is poor cyclability that originates from degradation of battery components, such as the cathode and electrolyte, in the presence of highly reactive Li
2
O
2
discharge products.
(1,2)

One problem is the low ionic and electronic conductivities of Li
2
O
2
, which disrupts the facile decomposition of Li
2
O
2
for good reversibility. The low conductivities of Li
2
O
2
could result in a large overpotential that leads to the decomposition of electrolytes and premature cell death.
(3)
Moreover, increases in the size of Li
2
O
2
products yield longer conductive pathways that impede the mobility of lithium ions and electrons. However, the discharge products Li
2
O
2
must be preferred to be abundant to support a large energy capacity. Therefore, a deep understanding of the mechanism for nucleation, growth and decomposition of Li
2
O
2
is necessary to improve the performance of LAB. Another challenge is the high reactivity of Li
2
O
2
that can cause deleterious side reactions with other components.
(4)
Each component of LAB, including the carbon, catalyst, electrolytes, and anode, must be carefully selected to tolerate and/or prevent such side reactions with Li
2
O
2
to enable high reversibility.

Previous reports
(5)
showed that the Gutmann donor number (DN, kcal mol
–1
) of the electrolyte strongly influences the growth mechanism of Li
2
O
2
and determines the resulting morphology. Electrolytes with a high DN such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, DN = 30), dimethylacetamide (DMAc, DN = 28), and dimethylformamide (DMF, DN = 27) promote the growth of large Li
2
O
2
particles in solution by the reduction of soluble LiO
2
in an electrolyte solution via the strong solvation of the Li ion. However, large toroidal Li
2
O
2
particles grown in solution are difficult to dissolve during charging because of the long ionic and electronic conduction lengths, as well as low conductivity of Li
2
O
2
. By comparison, electrolytes with low DN such as acetonitrile (AN, DN = 14.1) and tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME, DN = 16.6) form Li
2
O
2
in film morphologies through LiO
2
species mainly dissolved on the electrode surface via the weak solvation of the Li ion.
(5)
However, if the electrode surface is passivated with an insulating Li
2
O
2
layer, the growth of Li
2
O
2
particles halts upon eliminating the supply of Li ions and oxygen, which limits discharge capacity.

To reduce the overpotential during the operation, many research groups reported that carbon materials with solid catalysts (Ru, RuO
2
, etc.) or a redox mediator (RM) showed high capacity by improving the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity of the cathode.
(6,7)
However, while the solid catalysts promote high ORR and OER performances, they can also decompose electrolytes continuously. Moreover, the RM can transport from the cathode to the Li metal anode, causing unwanted side reactions.
(8)
Therefore, it appears difficult to implement catalysts as cathodes in LABs at this stage of the technology.

Carbon-based materials are frequently used as a promising cathode in LABs because of their light weights, high conductivity, large surface area, and low cost.
(9)
The cycle stability of LABs is also largely affected by the stability of the carbon materials.
(10)
Several research groups investigated non-carbon materials (Au, Co
3
O
4
, etc.
(11,12)
) and stable carbon such as heat-treated
13
C and carbon nanotubes (CNT) that are less reactive with electrolytes or oxygen discharge products in LABs.
(10,13)
Eliminating oxygen functional groups on the carbon surface could reduce the side reaction with oxygen discharge products. However, there is still limited understanding of the morphology and growth mechanisms of the discharge products by the carbon surface structure. We posit that the surface structure of the carbon material can influence interface between the carbon and electrolyte that promote specific nucleation growth conditions for Li
2
O
2
.

Generally, in Li ion batteries, the Li ions transfer between the cathode and electrolyte through a cathode electrolyte interfacial (CEI) layer.
(14−16)
The CEI layer is formed by interfacial reactions that involve the cathode and electrolyte. As a result, the properties of the CEI layer depend on the specific cathode and electrolyte that is used. High-performing CEI layer exhibits high ion conductivity and low electron conductivity to reduce the continuous decomposition of the electrolyte on the electrode.
(17)
For LABs, we hypothesized that the CEI layer would also be generated rapidly upon use due to interfacial reactions between the carbon cathode and electrolyte. In this case, Li
2
O
2
would form on the CEI layer and be influenced by the CEI layer. The CEI layer not only needs to block continuous electrolyte decomposition but also act as a seed layer for Li
2
O
2
formation. To the best of our knowledge, the influence of cathode material and electrolyte combinations on CEI layer formation have not been investigated in LABs. Here, we discover a mechanism of generation (nucleation and growth) and dissolution of Li
2
O
2
particles by the CEI layer in an LAB.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The cathode was prepared by dry mixing using carbon and PTFE (Daikin Industries, LTD). Ketjenblack 600JD (KB, Lion Corporation) and graphitic carbon (GC) were used as the carbon material, and PTFE acted as the binder for the cathode. GC was fabricated by heat-treating KB at 2700 °C for 10 h in argon gas. The cathode was made as a free-standing electrode by using a motor and roll-press. The thickness and loading weight of the cathodes were 100 μm and 5 ± 0.2 mg/cm
2
, respectively. All cathode materials were dried at 120 °C for 24 h in a vacuum oven to remove moisture. Two kinds of electrolytes were used. The electrolyte with the high donor number is 1 M LiNO
3
in DMAc, and the other one with a low donor number is 1 M LiTFSI in TEGDME. Lithium metal foil from Honzo metal was used in all coin cells.

CR2032 coin cells with cases with a 0.1 mm hole on the case were employed for electrochemical measurements of LAB. The cells consisted of the prepared carbon cathode (KB or GC) with a nickel form (400 μm, Dongjin metal tech.) as the gas diffusion layer, polyethylene (PE) separator (20 μm, SK innovation), and Li metal (500 μm, Honzo metal). Carbon paper and PE were soaked in 70 uL of the electrolyte (1 M LiNO
3
in DMAc or 1 M LiTFSI in TEGDME). To retard the evaporation of the electrolyte, the hole with the case of the coin cell was covered with a PET film (25 μm, Daeryung Industry). The polyethylene terephthalate (PET) film allows the penetration of O
2
gas at approximately 150 cc/day/m
2
though the pores of the polymer, which is measured by the oxygen transfer rate test system (C230, Labthink). All coin cells were assembled in a dry room (H
2
O < 0.1 ppm) and tested in an O
2
(99.999%) atmosphere at a pressure of 2 bar. The cells were discharged and charged at a current of 0.5 mA/cm
2
with 1, 5, and 10 mAh/cm
2
capacities and a voltage of 2.0–4.6 V at 25 °C.

The specific surface area of KB and GC was evaluated by a mercury porosimeter (Autopore IV 9500). The oxygen contents of the carbons were measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific). The morphology of discharge products and carbon surface was observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7800F, JEOL Ltd.). To avoid exposure to the moisture in air, all characterization was carried out in a dry room. The thin (few nm thick) scale layer on the surface of the carbon was analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL Ltd.). For ex situ SEM and TEM, the cathodes were extracted from the cycled cells and then measured. XPS was carried out to examine the composition of the product on the surface of the carbon in cathode. The crystal structure of the discharge products on the cathode were investigated by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, SmartLab, Rigaku). Differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy (DEMS) was carried out for gas analysis of the cells during operation. Impedance analysis (PARSTAT MC, Ameteck Princeton) was conducted to investigate the change in resistance of the cell during charging and discharging. Charge and discharge performances were carried out to analyze electrochemical properties by using a cycler (Arbin Instruments).

Pouch-type Li-air cells for the practical use were fabricated. The assembled cell was packaged with PET film to allow oxygen diffusion into the cell. The PET film also prevents leakage and evaporation of the electrolyte. Casting propylene (30 μm) was coated on the PET film (12 μm) as an adhesive to seal the pouch cell. Stainless steel (SUS) mesh (60 μm, MTI corporation) that is thinner than the nickel foam was applied as a gas diffusion layer and current collector for the cathode. The Li metal (100 μm, Honjo Metal) with the Cu current collector (6 μm, Honjo Metal) was used as anode. To stack the electrodes efficiently and improve energy density, a bilayer structure of the cathode and anode was used, such as carbon paper/SUS mesh/carbon paper and Li/copper foil /Li. A cathode and anode with sizes of 13.44 and 15.0 cm
2
, respectively, were applied in the pouch cell in this study. The dimension of the PE separator was 16.64 cm
2
. A total of 30 μL/cm
2
of electrolyte and 0.77 kgf/cm
2
of cell pressure were applied for the operation of the LAB pouch cell.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Many researchers have correlated the mechanism of Li
2
O
2
generation, such as solution and film growth, with the type of electrolyte used.
(1,3,5)
Here, electrolytes of LiNO
3
in DMAc and LiTFSI in TEGDME were employed as representative electrolytes for solution and film growth of Li
2
O
2
, respectively. Both NO
3
–
in LiNO
3
salt and DMAc solvent have high donor numbers.
(1)
By comparison, the electrolyte of LiTFSI in TEGDME consists of a salt and a solvent with low donor numbers and is generally employed in LABs due to their stabilities against oxygen radicals.
(18)
Carbon materials have large specific surface areas that make them suitable as cathodes that can achieve large electrochemical areas, such as KB600JD (1350 m
2
/g). Meanwhile, surface graphitic carbon (GC) has relatively lower specific surface areas (167 m
2
/g) and oxygen contents (∼1 at%) than KB (3.5 at%). We investigate the nucleation/growth mechanism of Li
2
O
2
and in particular the influence of the carbon surface under different electrolytes. Cells with four combinations of electrolyte and cathode combinations (KB/TEG, GC/TEG, KB/DMAc, and GC/DMAc) were investigated to understand the effect of the carbon surface under different electrolytes.

div.h3: 3.1. Electrochemical Performance and Characterization of Cells with KB/TEG, GC/TEG, KB/DMAc, and GC/DMAc
div.div:
Figure
1
shows the charge and discharge curves during the initial 5 cycles. The cells were cycled to 1 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off at 0.5 mA/cm
2
. The cell with KB/TEG combination showed increased overpotential after cycling, as shown in
Figure
1
a. This behavior may arise from side reactions among oxygen functional groups on the KB surface and the electrolyte or discharge products.
(10)
Therefore, GC was considered as a good cathode candidate in LABs because it lacked defects and surface oxygen groups. However, the GC/TEG cell shows the largest overpotential of above 4.0 V from the first charge (
Figure
1
b), which is causing the shortest cycling life (
Figure
1
e). By comparison, both KB and GC cells with LiNO
3
in DMAc could be cycled longer and had lower overpotential than cells with TEGDME. However, the cell with the KB/DMAc combination still showed relatively larger overpotential (>3.5 V) as compared to the GC/DMAc cell in
Figure
1
c. Surprisingly, despite the lower specific surface area of GC compared to KB, the GC/DMAc cell exhibited the largest capacity of 24 mAh/cm
2
, while the KB/DMAC had a lower 18 mAh/cm
2
capacity (
Figure S1
). While a solution growth mechanism of Li
2
O
2
would occur regardless of the specific surface area, the different discharge capacities for each type of carbon would involve the surface structure of carbon in the growth of Li
2
O
2
. In addition, the GC/DMAc cell exhibits interesting behavior in the transformation of the charge curve during cycling. Specifically, a new low plateau of 3.5 V during charging is observed after the first cycle, and the plateau at 3.5 V broadens gradually during the initial 5 cycles. After the charge voltage is stabilized, the cell with GC/DMAc had the longest cycle life, which extended beyond 100 cycles, as shown in
Figure
1
e. The stabilization behaviors shown here for the LAB is similar to a formation process of Li ion battery systems in which voltage stabilizes after only a few cycles.
(19,20)
This process was first observed in LABs and indicates the importance of appropriately selecting the combination of the cathode and electrolyte in LAB.

div.p:
Figure 1. Discharge–charge curves of cells with (a) KB/TEG, (b) GC/TEG, (c) KB/DMAc, and (d) GC/DMAc at a current density of 0.25 mA/cm
2
with a 1 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off. (e) Cycle retention of the various cells at a current density of 0.5 mA/cm
2
with a 1 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off.

div.div:
Differential electrochemical mass spectroscopy (DEMS) is a powerful tool for analyzing the emission and evolution of oxygen gas during LAB cycling. Gas emission and evolution by the cells while cycling was measured by using DEMS to interrogate the reversible oxygen evolution reaction (OER) during the cell operation. In
Figure
2
a, the cell with the KB/DMAc configuration shows low OER (67.6%) efficiency of the theoretical maximum on the first cycle (i.e., when 100% of the O
2
used in discharge evolves while charging). This cell emits a large quantity of CO
2
gas when operating above 3.9 V in
Figure S2
a. Thus, CO
2
emission increases with the number of cycles, while O
2
emission efficiency gradually decreases from 67.6% during the first cycle to 55.5% for the fifth cycle. Defects and oxygen functional groups on the surface of the KB carbon electrode readily react with electrolyte and discharge products, resulting in the irreversible formation of byproducts such as Li
2
CO
3
.
(10)
Byproducts can be decomposed at high voltages during charging. Thus, after discharging, the KB carbon surface generates byproduct by consuming additional electrolyte and oxygen and decreases the overall efficiency of OER over cycles. By comparison, the cell with the GC/DMAc combination shows improved OER efficiency of 85.6% at the fifth cycle, which is the highest value reported to date, shown in
Figure
2
a. This cell showed an initial plateau region for the OER with a small overpotential of ∼3.5 V, which could potentially increase the overall OER efficiency. Interestingly, a significant amount of O
2
was formed at the plateau at 3.5 V during the OER, indicating an efficient decomposition of discharge products. The OER efficiency of this cell increases with widening the plateau at 3.5 V during cycling shown in
Figure
2
b. We attribute this phenomenon to the effect of the interface between GC and DMAc that controls the formation of the Li
2
O
2
discharge product. In the case of the cell using KB/TEG, the cell has a low OER efficiency of 28.6% for the first cycle in
Figure S2
b. Even for the first cycle, the cell has a very low OER efficiency that implies the presence of a thick impurity layer on the KB surface during discharge, which may be a small amount of Li
2
O
2
and an abundance of other impurities like Li
2
CO
3
. Therefore, the first cycle had a low value of OER efficiency due to the reduced amount of Li
2
O
2
and the large amount of CO
2
gas from the decomposition of impurities during charging results in a small amount of oxygen evolution. The GC/TEG cell has a significant amount of CO
2
with the lowest O
2
gas evolution of 26% at the fifth cycle, majorly due to electrolyte decomposition by the large overpotential of the cell as shown in
Figure S2
c.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Oxygen evolution efficiencies and CO
2
evolution of cells with GC/DMAc, KB/DMAc, KB/TEG, and GC/DMAc configurations as analyzed by DEMS. Efficiencies here are normalized to their respective theoretical maximum values. (b) DEMS profile of the cell with GC/ DMAc during the first, second, and fifth cycles. The curves at the top of each plot are the integrated O
2
evolution curves associated with the charge–discharge plot of the GC/DMAc cell. The ideal 2e
–
/O
2
plot is represented as a dashed line.

div.div: Impedance analysis was conducted on cells with various combinations of carbon electrodes and electrolyte types to understand the interfacial phenomena on the cathode side. To interrogate specifically the interface between the carbon electrode and electrolyte, the cathodes from cycled cells were reassembled with a fresh Li metal and electrolyte to remove the effects of degradation resistance from the cycled Li metal. Furthermore, impedance of all cells was performed after full charging to investigate only the CEI layer on the carbon electrode before discharge products were formed.

Impedance spectra of cells with KB/TEG, GC/TEG, KB/DMAC, and GC/DMAC configurations obtained at OCV and before cycling are depicted in
Figure S3
. The impedance of all cells prior to cycling is negligible compared to cells in which the cathode was cycled, as shown in
Figure
3
. This indicates that the interface between fresh Li metal and the electrolyte did not substantially contribute to cell resistance. The impedance spectra of cells with TEGDME after the first cycle distinctly shows two semicircles at 10 kHz and 100 Hz, regardless the type of carbon electrode (KB or GC), as shown in
Figure
3
a,b. The semicircle corresponding to the higher frequency is associated with migration resistance of the surface-passivation layer (or CEI layer) on the cathode, while the other low-frequency semicircle is related to charge transfer resistance of the Li ions. Both resistances significantly increase after the fifth charge, which indicates an increased thickness of the CEI layer by continuous decomposition of the TEGDME electrolyte. The thick CEI layer impedes Li ion charge transfer.
Figure
3
c,d shows the impedance spectra of the cell with KB/DMAc and GC/DMAc configurations. These samples only permit comparisons of the interfacial resistance between the carbon cathodes and the DMAc electrolyte because fresh DMAc electrolyte and Li metal are used in both cells. Compared to cells with TEGDME, the impedance spectra from of the KB/DMAc and GC/DMAc cells show smaller semicircles in the 10 kHz region, which correspond to the CEI layer but similarly have semicircles at 100 Hz after the first cycle. After the fifth charge, however, impedance analysis of the KB/DMAc cell shows increased charge transfer resistance at 100 Hz while the small semicircle at 10 kHz becomes more distinct (
Figure
3
c). Although the GC/DMAc cell also exhibits a distinct semicircle in the 10 kHz region after the fifth charge, it also shows a dramatically decreased resistance in charge transfer (18 Ω) as illustrated in
Figure
3
d. We anticipate that the CEI layer could serve as a Li ion conductor and an electronic insulator, resulting in reduced decomposition of the DMAc on the GC electrode to promote reversible electrochemical reactions. With the GC surface coated in a material that efficiently conducts ions, the Li ion would be distributed evenly on the GC electrode surface. For Li ion batteries that are reversible, the CEI layer must promote high Li ion transfer and low decomposition while directly contacting both the electrolyte and electrode.
(17,21)
In addition, efficient ORR of the CEI layer should also be considered in a LAB.

div.p: Figure 3. Impedance analysis of cells with (a) KB/TEG, (b) GC/TEG, (c) KB/DMAc, and (d) GC/DMAc configurations after the first and fifth full charges. All cathodes were detached from cycled cells and reassembled with a new Li metal to investigate the resistance associated with cathode degradation.

div.div:
In this work, cells were cycled under practical capacity conditions (up to 5 mAh/cm
2
) to investigate their behaviors and potential for LAB with high energy densities. Cells with GC/DMAc, GC/TEG, and KB/DMAc configurations were subjected to gavalnostatic cycles, the results of which are shown in
Figure
4
. The cell with GC/TEG was excluded from this analysis because it could not discharge until a capacity of 5 mAh/cm
2
even at the first cycle. The cell with the KB/TEG configuration has a larger overpotential (discharge at 2.65 V with charge above 4.5 V) than when this cell was cycled at 1 mAh/cm
2
(
Figure
4
a). The large overpotential is maintained during cycling, causing the cell degradation at even 6 cycles. Meanwhile,
Figure
4
b shows that the KB/DMAc cell has a lower overpotential than the KB/TEG cell that is similar to the cell when operated at a 1 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off. However, the cell still has a higher overpotential with an increased capacity and short cycling performance of 20 cycles, as shown in
Figure
4
d. The cell with the GC/DMAc configuration shows the best performance at a 5 mAh/cm
2
cut-off (
Figure
4
c), which was cycled 64 times while showing the lowest overpotential. This cell also exhibits the transformation process of the charge curve during the initial cycles that corresponds to the behavior of the cell when cycled at 1 mAh/cm
2
. The galvanostatic discharge and charge curves remain stable after the transformation process completes after the first 5 cycles. The cell with the GC/DMAc configuration was disassembled to investigate the failure origins of the cycling performance, which revealed a dried cathode, anode, and separator in addition to the disappearance of the electrolyte. Reassembly by refilling the cell with a fresh electrolyte solution (1 M LiNO
3
in DMAc) yielded a cell that could approach 100 cycles. According to previous studies of LiNO
3
in DMAc electrolyte solutions, while the NO
3
–
of LiNO
3
protects the Li metal on the electrode, it can be difficult to maintain a protective layer during Li stripping and plating at capacities as high as 5 mAh/cm
2
. Therefore, the Li metal at the surface is continuously exposed to DMAc by repeated cycling because the protective layer on the Li metal could be degraded by a large amount of Li movement. This would gradually deplete the electrolyte and ultimately cause cell degradation.

div.p:
Figure 4. Charge and discharge curves of cells with (a) KB/TEG, (b) KB/DMAc, and (c) GC/DMAc during the first 5 cycles under a 5 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off and (d) capacity retention of cells at current densities of 0.5 mA/cm
2
under a 5 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off.

div.h3:
3.2. Li
2
O
2
Growth Mechanism at the Interface
div.div:
We investigated how the transformation process of charge curves observed during the first few cycles affects the generation and dissolution of discharge products in the GC/DMAc cell. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to observe the discharge products at the cathode that were formed during these initial cycles. Prior to analysis, all cells were discharged and charged at a current density of 0.5 mA/cm
2
with a limiting capacity of 5 mAh/cm
2
. The electron micrographs in
Figure
5
a were acquired from the cell with a KB/DMAc configuration and show discharge products with large (∼1 μm diameters) toroid-shaped morphologies that are sparsely distributed throughout the cell. This phenomenon corroborates previous reports in which electrolytes with a high donor number preferentially forms toroidal discharge products by a solution growth mechanism.
(5,22)
The morphologies and sizes of the large discharge products in the KB/DMAc cell do not change during cycling. Discharge products of large size cause high overpotential during charging due to the low conductivity of Li
2
O
2
, which is reflected in the charge curve of the KB/DMAc cell in
Figure
4
b.

div.p:
Figure 5. SEM micrographs of discharge products in cells with (a) KB/DMAc and (b) GC/DMAc at various cycles. Cathodes were prepared by discharging at 0.5 mA/cm
2
with a 5 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off.

div.div:
By comparison, operation of the GC/DMAc cell produces smaller (∼0.5 μm diameters) toroidal and disk-type particles that are densely distributed in the cell after the first discharge cycle, as shown in
Figure
5
b. After the third discharge, both types of discharge products, particles and films, start to merge together. After the fifth discharge, no particles are observed and all the discharge products are in film morphologies that cover nearly all of the GC electrode surface. We anticipated that at early cycles, the solution growth mechanism predominates to form toroidal Li
2
O
2
, but at later cycles, a film growth mechanism becomes dominant despite the use of an electrolyte with a high donor number.

Cells with other compositions, such as KB/TEG, GC/TEG, were also cycled and observed by SEM (
Figure S4
). The KB/TEG cell shows a non-uniform mixture of large toroids and film (
Figure S4
a). The large toroid and film discharge products increase in size after 5 cycles. As shown in
Figure S4
b, the cell with GC/TEG after the first cycle shows Li
2
O
2
discharge products in film morphologies but has a low discharge capacity. When a solvent has a low donor number, a LiO
2
intermediate by O
2
reduction is mainly formed on the electrode surface because the Li ion is solvated weakly in the solvent.
(1)
Then, reduction of the LiO
2
to Li
2
O
2
film occurs on the surface of the electrode. Therefore, in the case of GC/TEG, the LiO
2
intermediate would be mainly formed on the GC surface with a small area (167 m
2
/g), comparing to KB (1350 m
2
/g). In
Figure S1
, the full discharge capacity of GC/TEG is barely over 1 mAh/cm
2
in comparison with larger capacity (about 8.1 mAh/cm
2
) of KB/TEG. We assume that Li
2
O
2
film rapidly covers the surface of carbon in the presence of TEG, and further formation and growth of Li
2
O
2
is difficult due to the lack of LiO
2
on the carbon surface for reduction. After cycling, thicker films and some particles are observed and distributed non-uniformly, which causes short cycle life with a large overpotential. This implies that all of the discharge products that did not decompose during charging were accumulated on the carbon surface because of the poor solvation properties of the electrolyte.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were performed to investigate the phase of the discharge product on the cathode in the GC/DMAc cell (
Figure S5
). The Li
2
O
2
phase without impurities is clearly observed on entire cathodes after discharge, even after 5 cycles. After charging, the Li
2
O
2
phase disappears and leaves only the peaks associated with the GC and nickel foam current collector. This indicates that the discharge products in the thin film morphologies observed after the fifth cycle are not an impurity phase but rather are a pure Li
2
O
2
phase. This is also supported by the high OER ratio for the GC/DMAc cell, as shown in
Figure
2
a. Compared to the first discharge, the peaks corresponding to the Li
2
O
2
peaks broaden after the fifth discharge, which indicate that the Li
2
O
2
phase on the cathode converts from crystalline to amorphous during the first few cycles. On the contrary, in the cell with KB/DMAc, Li
2
O
2
after the first discharge is similar with what was observed at the fifth discharge, having a more crystalline phase compared to the GC/DMAc environment, as shown in
Figure S6
. Amorphous Li
2
O
2
has a higher ionic conductivity (7.10 × 10
–8
S/cm
–1
) than crystalline Li
2
O
2
(∼10
–19
S/cm).
(23)
We anticipate that the amorphous discharge product promotes the decomposition of Li
2
O
2
. Moreover, the thin film type of discharge product has a shorter distance for the Li ion and electrons to transfer in comparison to that in large toroids. Therefore, the GC/DMAc cell could promote the decomposition of Li
2
O
2
with a lower overpotential despite operating at a large capacity of 5 mAh/cm
2
because the amorphous film type of Li
2
O
2
is decomposed with exposure of the DMAc electrolyte. We confirmed that the morphology of the discharge product not only depends on the type of electrolyte but also on the surface of the carbon electrode. Li
2
O
2
in thin film morphologies could be grown even in electrolytes with high donor numbers as a result of the carbon surface.

We have investigated the reason that the morphology of the discharge products converts from toroid particles to films in cells with GC/DMAc. There could be a transition on the carbon surface that affects the environment for the nucleation and growth of the discharge products. Ex situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed to observe the carbon surface in the cells after cycling. To determine the environment in the cathode before Li
2
O
2
generation, the surface of carbon was observed after full charge to remove Li
2
O
2
and other impurities.

Pristine GC consists of several layers of a crystalline shell and an amorphous core, as depicted in
Figure
6
a, as compared to KB that is entirely amorphous (
Figure S7
a). After the first charge, a few island particles exist on the crystalline layers of the GC, as shown in
Figure
6
b. These were likely generated by reactions between GC and DMAc. The particles on the carbon surface remain even after the cell was charged to decompose Li
2
O
2
and other byproducts. The particles act as a seed layer to generate Li
2
O
2
prior to discharge. This layer seems like the CEI layer formed on the cathode in Li-ion battery systems after cycling, which stabilizes the voltage of the cell by reversible Li ion transfer though the CEI layer.
(17)
This process of seed layer formation is also consistent with the DEMS results for the GC/DMAc cell. As shown in
Figure
2
b, abundant emission of CO
2
gas with a low OER ratio during the first charge may be caused by the formation of a seed layer through decomposition of DMAc on GC.

div.p:
Figure 6. TEM micrographs of (a) pristine GC and cycled GC in a cell with GC and 1 M LiNO
3
in DMAc after the (b) first, (c) third, and (d) fifth charges. The yellow line indicates particles or layers of the seed.

div.div:
Seed particles gradually convert to film morphologies after the third charge (
Figure
6
c) and then become a uniform layer that covers the entire carbon surface after the fifth charge, as shown in
Figure
6
d. This implies that the uniform seed layer could reduce the direct contact of GC and DMAc that in turn reduces CO
2
gas emission by reactions between these components, which is reflected in the DEMS data of the GC/DMAc after 5 cycles (
Figure
2
b). The Li
2
O
2
discharge products must be grown on the seed layer of the GC during discharge. In the KB/DMAc cells, however, after the first charge, a few particles of various sizes form on the KB surface (
Figure S7
b). At the fifth charge, these particles increased in size and were non-uniformly distributed on the KB surface, as shown in
Figure S7
c. We anticipated that the particles were largely grown by the carbon corrosion and strong reaction of DMAc and KB, especially from the defects and oxygen functional groups. The particles could not be removed even after full charging the KB/DMAc cell. Irreversible byproduct formation interrupts the formation of Li
2
O
2
. Thus, the growth of Li
2
O
2
predominantly arises from a few seeds because seed sites for Li
2
O
2
are rare on the KB surface.

We posited that nucleation directly on the carbon surface may be difficult to achieve because the carbon surface itself supports no attraction reaction with oxygen molecules or Li ions. Initial nucleation sites for Li
2
O
2
could be defects on GC with reduced surface energy prior to the formation of a seed layer. The number of available nucleation sites would be few because of the low defect density in GC. Upon cycling, a seed layer with a high surface energy is formed on the GC surface, and it serves as additional nucleation sites. If the nuclei density is relatively high and the growing nuclei meet the neighboring nuclei, it would prefer the formation of film to minimize the surface energy.

An appropriate seed layer would help to promote efficient nucleation on the carbon surface. We confirmed that nucleation depends substantially on the composition of the carbon surface. According to the SEM image of KB after discharge (
Figure
5
a), even though the KB has a large specific surface area (1350 m
2
/g), it supports only a few Li
2
O
2
particles with large sizes. Reports show that oxygen functional groups on the carbon surface promote the formation of Li
2
CO
3
byproducts by reacting with the electrolyte.
(10,13)
We anticipate that byproducts like Li
2
CO
3
do not act as a good seed layers for Li
2
O
2
. Therefore, only a few nucleation sites for Li
2
O
2
could be formed on the KB surface. Growth of a few large toroidal particles of Li
2
O
2
is observed because their growth from a few seeds is preferred more than new nucleation on the impurity layer. By comparison, although GC has a smaller surface area (167 m
2
/g), it has many small Li
2
O
2
particles that are distributed on the surface. We ascertain that these products are formed by reactions between the GC surface and DMAc electrolyte and may be an appropriate seed layer to promote the formation of abundant Li
2
O
2
products. The seed layer on GC could preferentially attract Li ion and oxygen better than a bare carbon surface could. Therefore, the Li
2
O
2
formed at seed sites on the GC electrode are smaller than those grown on the KB because much nucleation on the seed layer is preferred versus growth in solution. When the GC/DMAc cell is cycled, the morphology of the Li
2
O
2
on the GC changes from small particles to films because simultaneous growth from the seed layer covers on the GC surface. To grow Li
2
O
2
uniformly as films, even distribution and composition of seeds are required.

To elucidate the seed layer grown on GC with DMAC in particular, the chemical state of the carbon surface was analyzed by using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) as shown in
Figure
7
. Cells were cycled five times to form seed layers, and the cathode was extracted for XPS analysis. Combined with the impedance data of the GC/DMAc cell, we anticipated that the seed layer on the GC would contribute to Li ion charge transfer and block continuous decomposition of the electrolyte. Moreover, according to the SEM and TEM results, the seed layer might also have efficient ORR properties that would promote high degrees of nucleation for Li
2
O
2
films.

div.p:
Figure 7. (a) C 1s, (b) O 1s, (c) N 1s, and (d) Li 1s XPS spectra of the cathode harvested from the GC/DMAc cell after the initial 5 cycles. The cathode was measured after charging until 5 mAh/cm
2
.

div.div:
XPS spectra of the GC electrode from the GC/DMAc cell operated for 5 cycles are shown in
Figure
7
. As shown in
Figure
7
a, the C 1s spectra of the GC cathode shows that C–C (284.6 eV, C 1s), C–H (285.2 eV, C 1s), and C–C–O (286.7 eV, C 1s) are observed in the same position with KB as described in
Figure S8
.
(24)
However, the GC cathode exhibits absence of peaks at 289.8 and 290.2 eV that corresponds to Li
2
CO
3
and ROCO
2
Li,
(24,25)
respectively, unlike the cathodes from the KB/DMAC cell. This indicates the presence of Li
2
CO
3
residue at the interface between KB and DMAc after cycling despite full charging. Li
2
CO
3
would act as a resistive layer because it has poor ionic (1.37 × 10
–8
S/cm) and electronic (∼10
–10
S/cm) conductivities,
(26)
which would interrupt Li ion movement on the carbon surface. Therefore, Li
2
O
2
growth from limited nucleation seeds would be preferred versus nucleation on Li
2
CO
3
on the KB surface.

Although the cell is charged fully after 5 cycles, some residue is also observed in the GC electrode of the GC/DMAC cell in
Figure
7
. The peaks corresponding to inorganic compounds, namely Li–N (55.5 eV, Li 1s) and N–O (532.2 eV, O 1s), might be involved in the formation of Li
3
N, LiO
x
N
y
or Li
2
N
x
O
y
.
(29)
By comparison, surface chemical components of pristine GC are shown in
Figure S9
. The 1% oxygen content in GC is lower than 3.5% in bare KB. No Li
2
CO
3
, Li–N, or N–O compounds are observed on the bare GC surface. Compounds containing both lithium and nitrogen could contribute to the uniform and rapid absorption of Li ions because they enhance Li ion conductivity (∼10
–4
S/cm).
(30)
The thin layer containing the Li–N compound promotes the formation of Li
2
O
2
by promoting Li ion transfer. In
Figure S10
, the Li
3
N peak at 398.5 eV N 1s is increasing upon cycles in the GC/DMAc. After 5 cycles, the intensity of the Li
3
N peak is maintained that is shown as a similar intensity at the 10th cycle. This result corresponds to other evidences (TEM, DEMS, impedance, and electrochemical process) for the formation of a seed layer. Few seeds (Li
3
N compound) were formed as islands on the surface of GC at the first cycle. After cycling, the seeds become a layer morphology gradually by meeting many neighboring seed islands formed by the continuous interfacial reaction. When the seed layer covers the surface of GC, the growth of the seed layer was not progressed by reducing decomposition of DMAc electrolyte due to low electronic conductivity (∼10
–12
S/cm) of Li
3
N.
(31)

On the other hand, peaks associated with LiO
2
(53.6 eV Li 1s, 528.3 eV O 1s) and Li
2
O
2
(531.2 eV O 1s) are detected on the GC electrode in
Figure
7
.
(27,28)
According to the previous report,
(32)
there are several disproportionation reaction steps with different free energy barriers from O
2
solution phase reduction to formation of the Li
2
O
2
bulk phase (O
2
–*
(sol) → LiO
2
(sol) → Li
2
O
2
(sol) → Li
2
O
2
(s)). When LiO
2
or Li
2
O
2
already exists on the carbon surface at the early stages of discharge, energy barrier required would be significantly reduced. Li ion reduction at LiO
2
on the carbon surface stabilizes to minimize the free energy of solvated LiO
2
.
(3)
Although LiO
2
exists on the carbon surface after charging, the fact that Li
2
O is converted to Li
2
O
2
during discharge establishes that the main discharge product is Li
2
O
2
rather than Li
2
O, according to DEMS and XRD analyses. Therefore, Li
2
O
2
could be grown in a film morphology uniformly on the entire GC surface. On the other hand, it was reported that NO
2
–
(406 eV, N 1s) conversion from NO
3
–
compounds (408 eV, N 1s) during charge promotes efficient Li
2
O
2
decomposition with a low overpotential.
(28,33)
However, growing thin films of Li
2
O
2
on carbon electrodes by NO
2
–
is difficult because NO
2
–
and NO
3
–
must be dissolved in the electrolyte solution as well as on the carbon surface. In this study, we anticipate that the nucleation and morphology of Li
2
O
2
depend on the composition of the seed layer even when electrolytes with a high donor number were used. In order to confirm this phenomenon and mechanism suggested, a carbon nanotube (CNT) as another potential carbon material was also examined with 1 M LiNO
3
in a DMAc electrolyte. The CNT was graphitized at 2700 °C temperature.
Figure S11
shows the discharge products in the CNT / DMAc cell after the first and fifth discharges. The results are consistent with GC/DMAc, as they showed same transition of Li
2
O
2
from toroidal to film. A schematic illustration of discharge product growth on the seed layer in GC/DMAc cells is shown in
Figure
8
, which is concluded based on the impedance, TEM, and XPS analyses in this study.

div.p:
Figure 8. Schematic illustration of the mechanism of Li
2
O
2
growth though the formation of a seed layer.

div.h3: 3.3. Cell Performance of LAB with a Seed Layer
div.div:
To further investigate the feasibility of LAB to achieve energy densities greater than Li ion batteries, the GC/DMAc cell was measured under large capacities of 10 mAh/cm
2
. The galvanostatic cycling profile in
Figure
9
a demonstrates that the overpotential for charging was clearly lower after the subsequent cycle in the GC/DMAc cell. After the formation process, the GC/DMAc cell exhibits greatly improved stability in working voltage, as shown in
Figure
9
a. This is the first report of a LAB showing reversible cycling at a large capacity (10 mAh/cm
2
). The cell cycled under 10 mAh/cm
2
also showed same transition of Li
2
O
2
from toroidal to film, which is consistent with the case of the lower capacity cut-off as shown in
Figure S12
.

div.p:
Figure 9. Cyclic and rate performance of the GC/DMAc cell. (a) Cycling performance conducted under a limited large capacity of 10 mAh/cm
2
at a current density of 1 mA/cm
2
. Galvanostatic charge and discharge curves are in the small box. (b) Voltage profiles for the GC/DMAc cell at different current densities ranging from 0.5 to 3.0 mA/cm
2
. Cell operated under limited capacities of 5 mAh/cm
2
. (c) Image of the pouch cell and (d) voltage profile of the pouch type LAB with 1.34 Ah cycled under a 10 mAh/cm
2
capacity cut-off at 25 °C.

div.div:
The failure of the GC/DMAc cell after cycling might be caused by a short circuit issue. The electrolyte was remained even after the cycling failure of the cell. After disassembling the cell, the Li metal electrode and separator from the cell were observed, as shown in
Figure S13
. Compared to the fresh Li metal (
Figure S13
a), black dots appeared on the separator and a thick impurity layer with yellow color covered the surface of the Li metal electrode (
Figure S13
b). We anticipate that Li dendrites penetrated into the PE separator by a large movement of Li during cycling. Moreover, the cell that was reassembled with the used PE, which includes a new cathode, electrolyte, and Li metal, still suffered short-circuit even at the first cycle. This demonstrates that the Li metal dendrites, which penetrated the PE separator, were responsible for the additional short-circuit. Consequently, even though the GC/DMAc cell afforded operation at larger capacities in the cathode, Li dendrites and side reactions between DMAc and Li metal hindered cycling stability. The rate performance of the GC/DMAc cell was evaluated from current densities of 0.5 to 3.0 mA/cm
2
, as shown in
Figure
9
b. The cycling stability of the GC/DMAc cell was retained with a small increase in the overpotential, even at a current density of 2.5 mA/cm
2
, while the cells with other compositions (KB/TEG, KB/DMAc, and GC/TEG) did not show stable cycling even at current densities of 1 mA/cm
2
. The seed layer formed on the surface of the GC could afford an abundance of lithium ions for ORR at high current densities.

In this study, we also fabricated a pouch-type Li-air cell with an energy density consistent with practical use. Stainless steel (SUS) mesh with porous structures was used as the gas diffusion layer (GDL)/current collector to deliver O
2
gas into the stacked cathode. This cell consisted of 10 unit cells that included stacked electrodes with a bilayer of Li metal/Cu foil/Li metal as an anode and GC/SUS/GC as a cathode, as shown in
Figure
9
c. The stacked electrodes were packed with PET film as the package film. PET film with a proper gas penetration rate (150 cc/day/m
2
) is very effective for retarding the evaporation and blocking leakage of the electrolyte as the package film. The effectiveness of PET film was confirmed through evaluation of a coin cell with PET as shown in
Figure S14
. Compared to the GC/DMAc cell with PET film, the cell without PET shows a shorter cycle life due to rapid electrolyte evaporation. After disassembling the finished cell without PET, the electrolyte was totally dried and a residue of Li dendrite was not observed on the separator, contrary to the cell with PET.

The LAB pouch cell was cycled at a capacity cut-off of 10 mAh/cm
2
and a current density of 0.5 mA/cm
2
, which represents 50% utilization of the theoretical capacity of 100 μm of Li metal. The practical capacity of the pouch cell on the cathode area (13.44 cm
2
× 10 layers) is 1.34 Ah. The working voltage of the pouch cell maintains 2.7 V during discharge, as depicted in
Figure
9
d. In previous reports, although LABs with capacities of above 10 mAh/cm
2
were previously reported, the reversibility was limited to the first cycle or a few cycles with an unstable voltage plateau.
(34,35)
This work reports, for the first time, the reversible reaction of an LAB pouch cell with high energy density. These results could suggest that LABs could be used in practical use. Cycling failure could be caused by the Li dendrites, which was established by confirming the presence of remaining lithium on the separator, as shown in
Figure S15
. To achieve longer stabilities for LABs with large capacities, further improvement in Li metal technology is needed to suppress dendrite formation and side reactions that involve Li metal.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We discovered how the interface between the carbon surface and electrolyte controls the morphology of Li
2
O
2
particles and highlighted its significance on the capacity and reversibility of the cell. Seed layers formed by the reaction between GC and the DMAc electrolyte, which has a high donor number, induced numerous nucleation sites for Li
2
O
2
growth in thin film morphologies with large capacity. The thin film type of Li
2
O
2
particles promoted dissolution with low overpotential during charging. A 1.34 Ah LAB pouch cell with a seed layer between the GC and DMAC demonstrated reversible cycling. We confirmed that not only the electrolyte but also the interface on the cathode electrode determines the nucleation and growth mechanism of Li
2
O
2
. The interfacial layer formed by reactions between the carbon and electrolyte could act as a seed for the nucleation of Li
2
O
2
. This could determine whether Li
2
O
2
assumes a thin film or toroidal morphology. These insights provide deep insight into the design of cathode materials and electrolyte selection for practical LABs with high energy densities. New understanding of the reaction chemistry that occurs at the interface between the cathode and electrolyte will accelerate the development of LAB technology. Although the development of technological processes should still be considered for commercializing LAB, such as stacking configurations and systems that promote O
2
diffusion into the cell, the LAB system is positioned as an attractive energy storage device for future mobility applications.

.

; XRD of the cathode from the cell with GC/DMAc at different cycles under a 5 mAh/cm

capacity cut-off; XRD of the cathode from the cell with KB/DMAc at the 1st and 5th discharge under a 5 mAh/cm

3
in DMAc after the (c) 1st discharge and (d) 5th discharge under a 5 mAh/cm

capacity cut-off; (a) TEM and (b) SEM of graphitized CNT and SEM image of the discharge product in the CNT electrode cell with CNT/1 M LiNO

Advances in understanding mechanisms underpinning lithium-air batteries
Aurbach, Doron; McCloskey, Bryan D.; Nazar, Linda F.; Bruce, Peter G.

A review. The rechargeable lithium-air battery has the highest theor. specific energy of any rechargeable battery and could transform energy storage if a practical device could be realized. At the fundamental level, little was known about the reactions and processes that take place in the battery, representing a significant barrier to progress. Here, we review recent advances in understanding the chem. and electrochem. that govern the operation of the lithium-air battery, esp. the reactions at the cathode. The mechanisms of O2 redn. to Li2O2 on discharge and the reverse process on charge are discussed in detail, as are their consequences for the rate and capacity of the battery. The various parasitic reactions involving the cathode and electrolyte during discharge and charge are also considered. We also provide views on understanding the stability of the cathode and electrolyte and examine design principles for better lithium-air batteries.

Recent advances in understanding of the mechanism and control of Li2O2 formation in aprotic Li-O2 batteries
Lyu, Zhiyang; Zhou, Yin; Dai, Wenrui; Cui, Xinhang; Lai, Min; Wang, Li; Huo, Fengwei; Huang, Wei; Hu, Zheng; Chen, Wei
Chemical Society Reviews
(

Aprotic Li-O2 batteries represent promising alternative devices for elec. energy storage owing to their extremely high energy densities. Upon discharge, insulating solid Li2O2 forms on cathode surfaces, which is usually governed by two growth models, namely the soln. model and the surface model. These Li2O2 growth models can largely det. the battery performances such as the discharge capacity, round-trip efficiency and cycling stability. Understanding the Li2O2 formation mechanism and controlling its growth are essential to fully realize the technol. potential of Li-O2 batteries. In this review, we overview the recent advances in understanding the electrochem. and chem. processes that occur during the Li2O2 formation. In the beginning, the oxygen redn. mechanisms, the identification of O2-/LiO2 intermediates, and their influence on the Li2O2 morphol. have been discussed. The effects of the discharge c.d. and potential on the Li2O2 growth model have been subsequently reviewed. Special focus is then given to the prominent strategies, including the electrolyte-mediated strategy and the cathode-catalyst-tailoring strategy, for controlling the Li2O2 growth pathways. Finally, we conclude by discussing the profound implications of controlling Li2O2 formation for further development in Li-O2 batteries.

Understanding the Chemical Stability of Polymers for Lithium-Air Batteries
Amanchukwu, Chibueze V.; Harding, Jonathon R.; Shao-Horn, Yang; Hammond, Paula T.
Chemistry of Materials
(

Recent studies showed that many aprotic electrolytes used in Li-air batteries are not stable against superoxide and peroxide species formed upon discharge and charge. However, the stability of polymers often used as binders and as electrolytes is poorly understood. The authors select a no. of polymers heavily used in the Li-air/Li-ion battery literature, and examine their stability, and the changes in mol. structure in the presence of com. Li2O2. Of the polymers studied, poly(acrylonitrile) (PAN), poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC), poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF), poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP), and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) are reactive and unstable in the presence of Li2O2. The presence of the electrophilic nitrile group in PAN allows for nucleophilic attack by Li2O2 at the nitrile C, before further degrdn. of the polymer backbone. For the halogenated polymers, the presence of the electron-withdrawing halogens and adjacent α and β H atoms that become electron-deficient due to hyperconjugation makes PVC, PVDF, and PVDF-HFP undergo dehydrohalogenation reactions with Li2O2. PVP is also reactive, but with much slower kinetics. However, the polymers poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE), Nafion, and poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA) appear stable against nucleophilic Li2O2 attack. The lack of labile H atoms and the poor leaving nature of the fluoride group allow for the stability of PTFE and Nafion, while the Me and methoxy functionalities in PMMA reduce the no. of potential reaction pathways for Li2O2 attack in PMMA. Poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) appears relatively stable, but may undergo some crosslinking in the presence of Li2O2. Knowledge gained from this work will be essential in selecting and developing new polymers as stable binders and solid or gel electrolytes for Li-air batteries.

The role of LiO2 solubility in O2 reduction in aprotic solvents and its consequences for Li-O2 batteries
Johnson, Lee; Li, Chunmei; Liu, Zheng; Chen, Yuhui; Freunberger, Stefan A.; Ashok, Praveen C.; Praveen, Bavishna B.; Dholakia, Kishan; Tarascon, Jean-Marie; Bruce, Peter G.

When lithium-oxygen batteries discharge, O2 is reduced at the cathode to form solid Li2O2. Understanding the fundamental mechanism of O2 redn. in aprotic solvents is therefore essential to realizing their technol. potential. Two different models have been proposed for Li2O2 formation, involving either soln. or electrode surface routes. Here, we describe a single unified mechanism, which, unlike previous models, can explain O2 redn. across the whole range of solvents and for which the two previous models are limiting cases. We observe that the solvent influences O2 redn. through its effect on the soly. of LiO2, or, more precisely, the free energy of the reaction LiO2* .dblharw. Li(sol)+ + O2-(sol) + ion pairs + higher aggregates (clusters). The unified mechanism shows that low-donor-no. solvents are likely to lead to premature cell death, and that the future direction of research for lithium-oxygen batteries should focus on the search for new, stable, high-donor-no. electrolytes, because they can support higher capacities and can better sustain discharge.

The structural design and synthesis of cathode materials with superior catalytic activity is still a major challenge for rechargeable lithium-oxygen batteries. Here we prepd. hierarchical Ru- and RuO2-foams as binder- and carbon-free electrocatalysts via an electrodeposition process using a hydrogen bubble template. The as-prepd. Ru- and RuO2-foams were grown vertically on stainless steel mesh, with a dendritic bracken-like structure and highly divided thin branches. These freestanding Ru- and RuO2-foams provide high catalytic activity, large space to accommodate the discharge products, short ion diffusion lengths and channels for rapid transport of oxygen and electrolytes. The hierarchically dendritic cathodes without carbon and binders present low charge/discharge overpotential, remarkable cyclability, good oxygen efficiency and reduced irreversible formation/decompn. The excellent performance of these foams, as characterized by systematic anal. and the facile fabrication approach provide an alternative method to develop advanced cathodes for Li-O2 batteries.

Li-O2 battery is one of the important next-generation energy storage systems, as it can potentially offer the highest theor. energy d. among battery chemistries reported thus far. However, realization of its high discharge capacity still remains challenging and is hampered by the nature of how the discharge products are formed, causing premature passivation of the air electrode. Redox mediators are exploited to solve this problem, as they can promote the charge transfer from electrodes to the soln. phase. The mechanistic understanding of the fundamental electrochem. reaction involving the redox mediators would aid in the further development of Li-O2 batteries along with rational design of new redox mediators. Herein, we attempt to monitor the discharge reaction of a Li-O2 battery in real time by liq.-phase transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Direct in situ TEM observation reveals the gradual growth of toroidal Li2O2 discharge product in the electrolyte with the redox mediator upon discharge. Moreover, quant. analyses of the growth profiles elucidate that the growth mechanism involves two steps: dominant lateral growth of Li2O2 into disclike structures in the early stage followed by vertical growth with morphol. transformation into a toroidal structure.

The Li-O2 battery is capable of delivering the highest energy d. among currently known battery chemistries and is thus regarded as one of the most promising candidates for emerging high-energy-d. applications such as elec. vehicles. Although much progress has been made in the past decade in understanding the reaction chem. of this battery system, many issues must be resolved regarding the active components, including the air electrode and electrolyte, to overcome the presently insufficient cycle life. In this work, we demonstrate that the degrdn. kinetics of both the air electrode and electrolyte during cycles can be significantly retarded through control of the crystallinity of the carbon electrode, the most frequently used air electrode in current Li-O2 batteries. Using 13C-based air electrodes with various degrees of graphitic crystallinity and in situ differential electrochem. mass spectroscopy anal., it is demonstrated that, as the crystallinity increases in the carbon, the CO2 evolution from the cell is significantly reduced, which leads to a 3-fold enhancement in the cyclic stability of the cell.

The rechargeable nonaq. lithium-air (Li-O2) battery is receiving a great deal of interest because, theor., its specific energy far exceeds the best that can be achieved with lithium-ion cells. Operation of the rechargeable Li-O2 battery depends critically on repeated and highly reversible formation/decompn. of lithium peroxide (Li2O2) at the cathode upon cycling. Here, we show that this process is possible with the use of a DMSO electrolyte and a porous gold electrode (95% capacity retention from cycles 1 to 100), whereas previously only partial Li2O2 formation/decompn. and limited cycling could occur. Furthermore, we present data indicating that the kinetics of Li2O2 oxidn. on charge is approx. 10 times faster than on carbon electrodes.

Rechargeable lithium-oxygen batteries have attracted extensive attention for their high energy d. However, the carbon corrosion, the undesired electrolyte decompn. catalyzed by carbon, and the irreversible reaction between carbon and the discharge product Li2O2 limit their performance. Herein we show the synthesis of sea-urchin-like cobalt oxide growing directly on nickel foam by a facile method, exhibiting several features. Furthermore, the macrosized voids built up by the 1D nanorods provide sufficient buffer space for Li2O2 deposition without blocking O2 diffusion. As a result, the battery displays high performance, including a high specific capacity of ∼3000 mA h g-1 based on the wt. of the whole electrode and long-life (∼1800 h, 60 cycles at a fixed capacity of 500 mA h g-1).

In lithium oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, controlling the structure of lithium peroxide (Li2O2) can reduce the large overpotential of the charge process as this affects the ionic and electronic conductivities of Li2O2. We demonstrate, for the first time, the in situ structural tuning of Li2O2 during the discharge process by virtue of the surface properties of carbon nanotube electrodes. We tailored carbon nanotube surfaces to decouple oxygen functional groups, defective edges, and graphitization, which directly influence the surface-binding affinity of O2 and LiO2. Consequently, conformal and completely amorphous Li2O2 films form in the presence of oxygen functional groups, which can facilely decomp. in the subsequent charge. In contrast, cryst. Li2O2 particles grow in more ordered carbon electrodes and consequently require higher overpotential for decompn. Our comprehensive study reveals the possibility of facile decompn. of Li2O2 by the surface engineering of carbon electrode and gives insights into the parameters to improve Li-O2 cell performance without any addnl. promoters such as nanoparticles or sol. redox mediators. In all, this work provides improved understanding of the general role of carbonaceous electrode surfaces toward the enhancement of discharge capacity, charge potential, and stability.

All solid-state batteries are of key importance in the development of next-generation energy storage devices with high energy d. Herein, we report the fabrication and operation of bulk-type 5 V-class all solid-state batteries consisting of LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode, Li10GeP2S12 solid-electrolyte, and Li metal anode. The 1st discharge capacity is about 80 mAh g-1 with an av. voltage of 4.3 V. The discharge capacity gradually decreases during the subsequent cycles. X-ray diffraction and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy measurements reveal that the capacity fading results from the growth of a resistive interfacial layer on the cathode composite. The development of suitable conductive additive and sulfide solid electrolyte materials is essential for the development of high-voltage all solid-state batteries.

The aprotic lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) battery has triggered tremendous efforts for advanced energy storage due to the high energy d. However, realizing toroid-like Li2O2 deposition in low-donor-no. (DN) solvents is still the intractable obstruction. Herein, a heterostructured NiS2/ZnIn2S4 is elaborately developed and investigated as a promising catalyst to regulate the Li2O2 deposition in low-DN solvents. The as-developed NiS2/ZnIn2S4 promotes interfacial electron transfer, regulates the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, and accelerates O-O bond cleavage, which are convincingly evidenced exptl. and theor. As a result, the toroid-like Li2O2 product is achieved in a Li-O2 battery with low-DN solvents via the solvation-mediated pathway, which demonstrates superb cyclability over 490 cycles and a high output capacity of 3682 mA h g-1. The interface engineering of heterostructure catalysts offers more possibilities for the realization of toroid-like Li2O2 in low-DN solvents, holding great promise in achieving practical applications of Li-O2 batteries as well as enlightening the material design in catalytic systems.

Gaining a thorough understanding of the reactions on the electrode surfaces of Li batteries is crit. for designing new electrode materials suitable for high-power, long-life operation. A technique for directly observing surface structural changes was developed that employs an epitaxial LiMn2O4 thin-film model electrode and surface x-ray diffraction (SXRD). Epitaxial LiMn2O4 thin films with restricted lattice planes (111) and (110) are grown on SrTiO3 substrates by pulsed laser deposition. In situ SXRD studies revealed dynamic structural changes that reduce the at. symmetry at the electrode surface during the initial electrochem. reaction. The surface structural changes commence with the formation of an elec. double layer, which is followed by surface reconstruction when a voltage is applied in the 1st charge process. TEM images after 10 cycles confirm the formation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer on both the (111) and (110) surfaces and Mn dissoln. from the (110) surface. The (111) surface is more stable than the (110) surface. The electrode stability of LiMn2O4 depends on the reaction rate of SEI formation and the stability of the reconstructed surface structure.

The max. total cond. at room temp. is ∼4 × 10-4 S/cm for the solely Ge contg. sample. The combination of vacuum-based Li thin film deposition and XPS is well suited to study the reactivity of the solid electrolyte membranes in contact with Li. As a major result, none of the materials studied is stable in contact with Li metal, and the reactive interaction between solid electrolytes and Li metal in terms of the formation of a mixed (ionic/electronic) conducting interphase (MCI) following the known SEI concept in liq. electrolytes are discussed.

Given their high theor. specific energy, Li-O batteries have received enormous attention as possible alternatives to current state-of-the-art rechargeable Li-ion batteries. However, the max. discharge capacity in nonaq. Li-O batteries is limited to a small fraction of its theor. value due to the build-up of insulating Li peroxide (Li2O2), the battery's primary discharge product. The discharge capacity can be increased if Li2O2 forms as large toroidal particles rather than as a thin conformal layer. Here, trace amts. of electrolyte additives, such as H2O, enhance the formation of Li2O2 toroids and result in significant improvements in capacity. The exptl. observations and a growth model show that the solvating properties of the additives prompt a soln.-based mechanism that is responsible for the growth of Li2O2 toroids. The authors present a general formalism describing an additive's tendency to trigger the soln. process, providing a rational design route for electrolytes that afford larger Li-O battery capacities.

The inhomogeneous deposition/dissoln. of Li metal and an unstable SEI layer are still tough issues for lithium metal batteries, causing severe safety problems and low Coulombic efficiency. In this paper, we design an artificial SEI layer based on in situ polymn. of Et α-cyanoacrylate precursor with LiNO3 additive. The CN- and NO3- groups can react with lithium metal during cycling to form a nitrogenous interface inorg. layer, facilitating ions conduction and blocking further undesirable interface reaction. The poly(Et α-cyanoacrylate) with excellent mech. property presents as the dominate org. species in the artificial SEI layer to offer a uniform and firm protective outer layer. A lithium metal battery with this artificial SEI film exhibits a capacity retention of 93% even after 500 cycles at a rate of 2C. A smooth surface morphol. of the lithium metal anode is obtained without any cracks and dendrites.

The stability of electrolyte solns. during lithium-oxygen cells operation is of great importance and interest. This is because oxides formed during redn. are strong nucleophiles which can initiate solvent decompn. The highly polar amide based solvents have come to the fore as possible candidates for Li-O2 applications. They show typical cycling behavior as compared to other solvents; however, their stability toward lithium oxides is shrouded in doubt. The present study has focused on Li-O2 cells contg. electrolyte solns. based on DMA/LiNO3. We have used various anal. tools, to explore the discharge-charge processes and related side reactions. The data obtained from FTIR, NMR, XPS, and EQCM all support a rational decompn. mechanism. The formation of various side products during the course the first discharge, leads to the conclusion that amide based solvents are not suitable for Li-O2 applications; however, electrolyte soln. decompn. reduces the OER overpotential by forming oxidn. mediators.

The lithium metal anode is regarded as a promising candidate in next-generation energy storage devices. Lithium nitrate (LiNO3) is widely applied as an effective additive in ether electrolyte to increase the interfacial stability in batteries contg. lithium metal anodes. However, because of its poor soly. LiNO3 is rarely utilized in the high-voltage window provided by carbonate electrolyte. Dissoln. of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolyte is realized through an effective solvation regulation strategy. LiNO3 can be directly dissolved in an ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate electrolyte mixt. by adding trace amts. of copper fluoride as a dissoln. promoter. LiNO3 protects the Li metal anode in a working high-voltage Li metal battery. When a LiNi0.80Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode is paired with a Li metal anode, an extraordinary capacity retention of 53 % is achieved after 300 cycles (13 % after 200 cycles for LiNO3-free electrolyte) and a very high av. Coulombic efficiency above 99.5 % is achieved at 0.5 C. The solvation chem. of LiNO3-contg. carbonate electrolyte may sustain high-voltage Li metal anodes operating in corrosive carbonate electrolytes.

A lithium conductive Li3N film is successfully prepd. on Li metal surface by the direct reaction between Li and N2 gas at room temp. X-ray diffraction, Auger electron spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry, SEM, AC impedance, cathodic polarization and galvanostatic charge/discharge cycling tests are applied to characterize the film. The Li3N protective film is tight and dense with high stability in the electrolyte. Its thickness is >159.4 nm and much bigger than that of a native SEI film formed on the lithium surface as received. An exchange current as low as 3.244 × 10-7 A demonstrates the formation of a complete SEI film at the electrode|electrolyte interface with Li3N modification. The SEI film is effective in preventing the corrosion of the Li electrode in liq. electrolyte, leading to a decreased Li|electrolyte interface resistance and an av. short distance of 3.16 × 10-3 cm for Li ion diffusion from electrolyte to Li surface. The Li cycling efficiency depends on N2 exposing time and is obviously enhanced by the Li3N (1 h) modification. After cycling, a dense and homogeneous Li layer deposits on the Li3N (1 h) modified Li surface, instead of a loose and inhomogeneous layer on the Li surface as received.

Zhang, Yelong; Zhang, Xinmin; Wang, Jiawei; McKee, William C.; Xu, Ye; Peng, Zhangquan

Discharging of the aprotic Li-O2 battery relies on the oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) producing Li2O2 in the pos. electrode, which remains incompletely understood. Here, we report a mechanistic study of the Li-ORR on a model system, i.e., an Au electrode in a Li+ DMSO (DMSO) electrolyte. By spectroscopic identification of the reaction intermediates coupled with d. functional theory calcns., we conclude that the formation of O2- and LiO2 in the Li-ORR critically depends on electrode potentials and dets. the Li2O2 formation mechanism. At low overpotentials (> 2.0 V vs Li/Li+) O2- is identified to be the first surface intermediate, which diffuses into the bulk electrolyte and forms Li2O2 therein via a soln.-mediated disproportionation mechanism. At high overpotentials (ca. 2.0-1.6 V vs Li/Li+) LiO2 has been obsd., which can rapidly transform to Li2O2 by further electro-redn., suggesting a surface-mediated mechanism. The soln.-mediated Li2O2 formation that can account for the widely obsd. toroid-shaped discharged Li2O2 particles has also been thoroughly examd. Thus, O2- formation controls the overall reaction onset potential, and LiO2 formation demarcates the change from a soln.- to surface-mediated reaction mechanism. The new findings and improved understandings of the Li-ORR in DMSO will contribute to the further development of aprotic Li-O2 batteries.

Sharon, Daniel; Hirsberg, Daniel; Afri, Michal; Chesneau, Frederick; Lavi, Ronit; Frimer, Aryeh A.; Sun, Yang-Kook; Aurbach, Doron

The development of a successful Li-O2 battery depends to a large extent on the discovery of electrolyte solns. that remain chem. stable through the redn. and oxidn. reactions that occur during cell operations. The influence of the electrolyte anions on the behavior of Li-O2 cells was thought to be negligible. However, it has recently been suggested that specific anions can have a dramatic effect on the chem. of a Li-O2 cell. In the present paper, we describe how LiNO3 in polyether solvents can improve both oxygen redn. (ORR) and oxygen evolution (OER) reactions. In particular, the nitrate anion can enhance the ORR by enabling a mechanism that involves solubilized species like superoxide radicals, which allows for the formation of submicronic Li2O2 particles. Such phenomena were also obsd. in Li-O2 cells with high donor no. solvents, such as DMSO DMF and dimethylacetamide (DMA). Nevertheless, their instability toward oxygen redn., lithium metals, and high oxidn. potentials renders them less suitable than polyether solvents. In turn, using catalysts like LiI to reduce the OER overpotential might enhance parasitic reactions. We show herein that LiNO3 can serve as an electrolyte and useful redox mediator. NO2- ions are formed by the redn. of nitrate ions on the anode. Their oxidn. forms NO2, which readily oxidizes to Li2O2. The latter process moves the OER overpotentials down into a potential window suitable for polyether solvent-based cells. Advanced anal. tools, including in situ electrochem. quartz microbalance (EQCM) and ESR plus XPS, HR-SEM, and impedance spectroscopy, were used for the studies reported herein.

Nomura, Akihiro; Ito, Kimihiko; Kubo, Yoshimi

Lithium-air batteries (LABs) are expected to provide a cell with a much higher capacity than ever attained before, but their prototype cells present a limited areal cell capacity of no more than 10 mAh cm-2, mainly due to the limitation of their air electrodes. Here, we demonstrate the use of flexible carbon nanotube (CNT) sheets as a promising air electrode for developing ultra-high capacity in LAB cells, achieving areal cell capacities of up to 30 mAh cm-2, which is approx. 15 times higher than the capacity of cells with lithium-ion battery (LiB) technol. (∼2 mAh cm-2). During discharge, the CNT sheet electrode experienced enormous swelling to a thickness of a few millimeters because of the discharge product deposition of lithium peroxide (Li2O2), but the sheet was fully recovered after being fully charged. This behavior results from the CNT sheet characteristics of the flexible and fibrous conductive network and suggests that the CNT sheet is an effective air electrode material for developing a com. available LAB cell with an ultra-high cell capacity.

A 500 mAh Li-Air battery is assembled using cell components and a structure that enable the construction of a high specific energy battery. Carbon nanotubes are used in the cathode so that the pore vol. can be adjusted to reduce the amt. of electrolyte while a high specific capacity of the cathode is maintained. Polymer ionic liq. is used in the electrolyte layer, and the wt. of the cathode and electrolyte layer is 5.5 mg cm-2. The cell structure, which is prepd. by folding a three-layer assembly of Li metal/electrolyte layer/cathode, reduces the wt. contribution of the sealing and manifold materials. By folding the three-layer assembly ten times, a 500 mAh Li-Air battery with dimensions of 7 cm × 1 cm × 0.23 cm is prepd. The battery yields an areal capacity of 3.6 mAh cm-2 and a specific capacity of 4400 mAh g-1carbon, and the resulting specific energy and energy d. are 1230 Wh kg-1 and 880 Wh L-1, resp. The battery is able to cycle seven times at 500 Wh kg-1 before an abrupt decrease in its capacity is noted.

Advances in understanding mechanisms underpinning lithium-air batteries
Aurbach, Doron; McCloskey, Bryan D.; Nazar, Linda F.; Bruce, Peter G.

A review. The rechargeable lithium-air battery has the highest theor. specific energy of any rechargeable battery and could transform energy storage if a practical device could be realized. At the fundamental level, little was known about the reactions and processes that take place in the battery, representing a significant barrier to progress. Here, we review recent advances in understanding the chem. and electrochem. that govern the operation of the lithium-air battery, esp. the reactions at the cathode. The mechanisms of O2 redn. to Li2O2 on discharge and the reverse process on charge are discussed in detail, as are their consequences for the rate and capacity of the battery. The various parasitic reactions involving the cathode and electrolyte during discharge and charge are also considered. We also provide views on understanding the stability of the cathode and electrolyte and examine design principles for better lithium-air batteries.

Recent advances in understanding of the mechanism and control of Li2O2 formation in aprotic Li-O2 batteries
Lyu, Zhiyang; Zhou, Yin; Dai, Wenrui; Cui, Xinhang; Lai, Min; Wang, Li; Huo, Fengwei; Huang, Wei; Hu, Zheng; Chen, Wei
Chemical Society Reviews

Aprotic Li-O2 batteries represent promising alternative devices for elec. energy storage owing to their extremely high energy densities. Upon discharge, insulating solid Li2O2 forms on cathode surfaces, which is usually governed by two growth models, namely the soln. model and the surface model. These Li2O2 growth models can largely det. the battery performances such as the discharge capacity, round-trip efficiency and cycling stability. Understanding the Li2O2 formation mechanism and controlling its growth are essential to fully realize the technol. potential of Li-O2 batteries. In this review, we overview the recent advances in understanding the electrochem. and chem. processes that occur during the Li2O2 formation. In the beginning, the oxygen redn. mechanisms, the identification of O2-/LiO2 intermediates, and their influence on the Li2O2 morphol. have been discussed. The effects of the discharge c.d. and potential on the Li2O2 growth model have been subsequently reviewed. Special focus is then given to the prominent strategies, including the electrolyte-mediated strategy and the cathode-catalyst-tailoring strategy, for controlling the Li2O2 growth pathways. Finally, we conclude by discussing the profound implications of controlling Li2O2 formation for further development in Li-O2 batteries.

Understanding the Chemical Stability of Polymers for Lithium-Air Batteries
Amanchukwu, Chibueze V.; Harding, Jonathon R.; Shao-Horn, Yang; Hammond, Paula T.
Chemistry of Materials
(
2015
),

(

0897-4756

(
American Chemical Society
